content.text: Java is a high-level, class-based, object-oriented programming language.
It is designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible.
Java applications are typically compiled to bytecode that can run on any Java Virtual Machine (JVM).
Java was developed by James Gosling and his team at Sun Microsystems in 1995.
Originally, Java was designed for interactive television, but it was too advanced for the digital cable television industry.
Later, Java was redesigned for web applications and became very popular.

content.text: JVM is an abstract machine that enables a computer to run Java programs.
It converts Java bytecode into machine code.
JVM provides memory management, garbage collection, and security.
JDK is a software development kit required to develop Java applications.
It includes the Java compiler (javac), JRE, and development tools.
Without JDK, you cannot compile Java programs.
JRE provides libraries and JVM to run Java programs.
It does not contain development tools like compiler.
End users only need JRE to run Java applications.

sections.heading: Difference between JDK, JRE, and JVM

items: JDK contains JRE along with development tools.

content.text: In simple terms: JDK > JRE > JVM.

items: Java source code is written in a .java file.
The compiler converts source code into bytecode (.class file).
The JVM loads the bytecode and executes it.
Output is produced on the console.
